title: Basic Authentication Heap Overflow

profile.name: Internet Bug Bounty
profile.about: The Internet Bug Bounty rewards security research into vulnerabilities impacting Open Source Software Projects.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
An attacker can get arbitrary data overflowed in the heap via Basic Authorization base64 blob. Even when basic auth isn't configured.

## Report sent to developers

When calling HttpHeader::getAuth the field value will be base64 decoded. The call to the decode method doesn't ensure that the buffer decodedAuthToken is large enough for the decoded string leading to a heap overflow. 

```
static char decodedAuthToken[8192]; 
struct base64_decode_ctx ctx; base64_decode_init(&ctx); 
size_t decodedLen = 0;
 if (!base64_decode_update(&ctx, &decodedLen, reinterpret_cast<uint8_t*>(decodedAuthToken), strlen(field), field) || !base64_decode_final(&ctx)) 
{ return NULL; } 
decodedAuthToken[decodedLen] = '\0'; 
```
```
(gdb) p decodedLen $21 = 43011
```


 In my repo steps I make an FTP request to squid-internal-mgr. Any user can reach this code since the Manager regex doesn't check for FTP protocol. A user can't access any real actions from cache manager though, just are able to reach the part of the code that will decode the header. 

## Steps To Reproduce:

1) make the following get request 

```
GET ftp://<squid_name>:<squid_port>/squid-internal-mgr/menu HTTP/1.1 

Authorization: Basic  











```

## Supporting Material/References:
http://www.squid-cache.org/Advisories/SQUID-2019_5.txt
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-12527

## Impact

In my repo it simply will decode A's to the heap overflowing adjacent objects. Since this data is base64 decoded there are no restrictions on the data the attacker can overflow the heap with. The attacker is also able to control how much they overflow the heap by allowing for finer control of their attack.

An attacker could use this to get remote code execution by overflowing an adjacent virtual table, or other crititcal heap memeber to work their way to remote code execution.

activities.message:
Hi @jeriko_one 

Thank you for your submission. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Kind regards,
@ktistai

Hi @jeriko_one , 

Since this is a memory corruption issue, can you share the OS you have used for testing, as well as any other specific settings that have to be done during the set-up (if there are any). 

If you have used a specific way of installing Squid, can you share that also with us? 

Thanks, 
@ktistai

Thank you for your questions. This is the first time I've reported something so any feedback is appreciated. 

I'm using Gentoo x86_64, I built Squid from source 4.7

Below is how I built Squid. 

```
basic_auth_helpers="DB fake getpwnam NCSA LDAP PAM POP3 RADIUS SASL SMB SMB_LM"
export CFLAGS="-O0 -g  -fsanitize=address"
export CXXFLAGS="${CFLAGS}"
"./configure" "--prefix=/home/j1/h4x/squid/squid-debug" \
		"--enable-auth" \
		"--enable-auth-basic=${basic_auth_helpers}" \
		"--enable-auth-digest=file"\
		"--with-openssl" \
		"--enable-ssl-crtd" \
		"--enable-ssl" \
		"--enable-cache-digests" \
		"--enable-esi" \
		"--enable-icmp" 

make; make install
```

The exact command I was using to repo it is as following

```
cat long_auth.txt | nc <squid ip> <squid port>
```

When I run Squid I use the following command
```
 ASAN_OPTIONS="abort_on_error=true" ./sbin/squid --foreground -d 100
```

I'm unable to upload the file long_auth which is just the HTTP request I put in my repo steps for some reason. 

Below is the ASAN report. ASAN reports it on the read instead of the write since the buffer is on declared as static, and is in the bss section. 

==11027==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: global-buffer-overflow on address 0x5654fe8d1160 at pc 0x7f85b366383d bp 0x7ffdfae7f690 sp 0x7ffdfae7ee38
READ of size 46084 at 0x5654fe8d1160 thread T0

Hi @jeriko_one , 

While building this, I am runnning into quite a lot of issues when making the ```make``` file with configure, motly because of missing development libraries. I managed to install some, but for this one I have no clue what is being used: 

```
configure: error: Basic auth helper LDAP ... found but cannot be build
``` 

What library/software do I need to install for LDAP (and any other conf prerequisites)?

Thanks, 
@ktistai

Which distro are you using? It might be easier just to install Squid in your distro then build it, that way it'll pull dependencies for you. 

In Gentoo you can see all dependencies via the ebuild file /usr/portage/net-proxy/squid/squid-X.X.ebuild.

LDAP comes from net-nds/openldap

The configure options I sent were enabling a lot of features that are irrelevant to this particular issue since I was testing many things. 

You can simply use an empty configure and still have Squid hit this issue

```
./configure --prefix=<install dir>
```

Let me know if you need anymore info.
Installing squid as a package actually made the configuration work like a charm. It's now compiling, hopefully it won't be taking long.

Hi @jeriko_one , 

I have Squid up and running. I've made some requests to my server, yet it's not showing the memory error. I am building it again, and made sure the ```address sanitizer``` cflags and libasan are installed, but if there is anything else I should do please let me know. My guess is that asan is not installed properly on my system.

You could check by using ldd on Squid to see if it is compiled in. 

```
ldd squid | grep asan
```

Should show libasan. 

It could be the markdown has messed up the header. Whenever I try to upload a file that has the request I get an error. Is there another way I can send you the file?

Below I try to describe it to you. 
<blob> will be the following base64 encoded blob

```

```

```
GET ftp://<squid server>:<squid port>/squid-internal-mgr/menu HTTP/1.1
Authorization: Basic <blob>
<tab><blob> (repeat 15 times)
<\r\n>
<\r\n>
```

Hi @jerioko_one, 

Libasan was not linked to the executable, at least not statically. If it's dinamically loaded at runtime, I did not check for that. 

I am going to add libasan in the cflags, hopefully that will do the trick. If there is anything else to be done, please let me know (maybe squid has already an libasan configuration?). 

Thanks, 
@ktistai

Squid does not have a asan configuration that I know of. I used  CFLAGS to enable Asan. 

```
CFLAGS="-O0 -g -fsanitize=address" CXXFLAGS="${CFLAGS}" ./configure
```

Another way you could check is via /proc

```
grep asan /proc/<Squid PID>/maps
```

Hi @jeriko_one I have done the needed conf modifications and also added a linker to the chain, as it was needed on my machine.(```CFLAGS="-O0 -g -fsanitize=address" CXXFLAGS="${CFLAGS}" ./configure LIBS='-ldl'``` is the command I used) However, it doesn't build asan into the binary. I will try to see what went wrong, maybe the library is not installed corectly (libasan). Thanks, @ktistai PS: I am also getting this weird error from squid: ```

ERROR

The requested URL could not be retrieved

The following error was encountered while trying to retrieve the URL: ftp://167.71.50.111:3128//squid-internal-mgr/menu

Access Denied.

Access control configuration prevents your request from being allowed at this time. Please contact your service provider if you feel this is incorrect.

```

Which distro are you using? I believe if address sanitizer wasn't built into your compiler that the compiler would throw an unknown option error. Are you sure it's not just linked dynamically? 

Is Squid on another machine maybe a VM? By default squid only allows IPs that are defined in the acl localnet and localhost defined in squid.conf.

If you're accessing it from an address that isn't that you'll have to create a new acl in the squid.conf

You can grant access to a specific IP using the following
```
acl tester src <IP>
```

Further down you'll see some allow and deny rules such as

```
http_access allow localnet
http_access allow localhost

http_access deny all
```

You'll want to put your new acl in the allow list

```
http_access allow localnet
http_access allow localhost
http_access allow tester
http_access deny all
```

When you run Squid are you using the following command?

```
 ASAN_OPTIONS="abort_on_error=true" ./sbin/squid --foreground -d 100
```

By default Squid will write error messages to a file, I found that the ASAN report wasn't being printed in gdb unless I set those options. 

Is there an email I can reach you at? I think the repo you're doing is incomplete. I cannot upload the file that has the complete request I keep getting an error even after disabling all plugins. Whenever I copy paste the request that triggers the behavior the formatting is messed up, and the formating is crucial for Squid accepting it.

Oh I was able to upload it! I just needed to change the extension of the file.

Please replace <sever> and <port> with  the appropriate values for your setup.

Run squid in one terminal

```
 ASAN_OPTIONS="abort_on_error=true" ./sbin/squid --foreground -d 100
```

In another issue this command

```
cat long_auth.txt | nc <server> <port>
```

Then the Asan message should appear. Squid will restart the child process so you'll have to scroll up to see the message, alternatively you can attach gdb to the squid child process. WIth the default config you should see 2 entries if you do pgrep squid, the second is the child process which you need to attach to.

@jeriko_one , 

You should be able to upload a file here, it's fairly straightforward. We cannot share email that we use to work. 

Regarding your question, I do use that command, but without the foreground parameter, as it's not working for me. I do have stdout on the screen though. 

In gdb, I was expecting to see an exception of some sort in the heap, and I would have considered the issue triaged (for memory corruption). 

I will forward this to the team, maybe it's something I am doing wrong. 

Thanks, 
@ktistasi

Please refer to my previous comment for the full request needed. I was able to upload it after changing the extension of the file to .txt. 

In your screenshot I see that you're using netcat, but aren't catting anything into it. The formatting of the request is crucial for Squid to process it. 

Please use the attachment long_auth.txt, changing <server> and <port> in the first line of the file to proper values for your setup. 

Running squid as

```
$ ASAN_OPTIONS="abort_on_error=true" ./sbin/squid -d 100
```

Should provide debug messages to stdout. I'd leave this terminal open as this is where your asan output will show up. --foreground isn't necessary, but will ensure that the terminal isn't used for somethign else. What errors are you getting with --foreground

You can attach gdb, but ensure it's the child process

```
gdb -q -p $(pgrep squid |tail -n 1)
```

Please use cat to pipe the request into netcat. That way the formatting will be correct

```
cat long_auth.txt | nc <server> <port>
```

Now in gdb you will hit a SIGABRT

```
Program received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.
0x00007fb947cf61d7 in raise () from /lib64/libc.so.6

The terminal you started Squid from should have outputed the crash log.

@jeriko_one , Still no crash on my side, but I am certain it's because of the ACL. This is the error I am getting, and I think the code that is vulnerable is not reached, at all. ``` /head>

ERROR

The requested URL could not be retrieved

The following error was encountered while trying to retrieve the URL: ftp://167.71.50.111:3128/squid-internal-mgr/menu

Access Denied.

Access control configuration prevents your request from being allowed at this time. Please contact your service provider if you feel this is incorrect.

``` I've already flagged the report for Squid's team and as soon as there is more info, we will let you know. Thanks, @ktistai
You could also try it on the box that has Squid since that will already have the acl. This way you can confirm if it's an acl or repo problem.

Another thing I just noticed about your repo is that you're using the IP. Please use the hostname when making the request

```
ftp://<squid hostname>:<port>
```

That is the only way the request will be marked as internal, and will reach the vulnerable code. 

Fro me my hostname is set in

/etc/conf.d/hostname

I can also get it via the command

```
$ hostname
g64
```

Looking at the code you could also set it via the config option

```
visable_hostname <hostname>
```

If that still doesn't work you could try setting a breakpoint on 

```
getMyHostname
```

and see what it returns, and use that in the repo.
